4.Hassan Turki and his Ras Kamboni Briages were part of Hizbul Islam from January 2009 until February 2010 when he led a faction of defectors which joined al-Shabaab.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/201002020211.html Notorious Islamist Guerrilla Leader Joins Al Shabaab], 2 February 2010 }} {{Campaignbox War in Somalia (2009â)}} {{Campaignbox Somali Civil War}} [[File:Somalia states regions districtsJuly1520091.png|200px|right|thumb|Situation of the war in Somalia back in mid-July 2009.]] The '''2009âpresent phase of the [[Somali Civil War]]''' is concentrated in southern [[Somalia]]. It began in early February 2009, with the conflict between, on the one hand, the forces of the Somali [[Transitional Federal Government]] assisted by [[African Union]] peacekeeping troops, and on the other, various militant Islamist and factions. The violence has displaced thousands of people residing in [[Mogadishu]], the nation's capital. The conflict has seen [[sectarian]] violence between the moderate [[Sufi]]s [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a|ASWJ]], and the Islamists [[Al-Shabaab]]. ==Background== {{main|War in Somalia (2006â2009)}} Established in 2004 and internationally recognized, the [[Transitional Federal Government]]'s (TFG) support in Somalia was waning until the [[United States]]-backed 2006 intervention by the Ethiopian military, which helped drive out the rival [[Islamic Courts Union]] (ICU) in Mogadishu and solidify the TFG's rule.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpolicy.org/component/content/article/153/26334.html |title=Ethiopian Invasion of Somalia |publisher=Globalpolicy.org |date=2007-08-14 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} Following this defeat, the ICU splintered into several different factions. Some of the more radical elements, including [[Al-Shabaab (Somalia)|Al-Shabaab]], regrouped to continue their insurgency against the TFG and oppose the Ethiopian military's presence in Somalia. Throughout 2007 and 2008, Al-Shabaab scored military victories, seizing control of key towns and ports in both central and southern Somalia. At the end of 2008, the group had captured [[Baidoa]] but not Mogadishu. By January 2009, Al-Shabaab and other militias had managed to force the Ethiopian troops to withdraw from the country, leaving behind an underequipped [[African Union]] (AU) peacekeeping force.{{cite web|author=United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees |url=http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/publisher,USCIRF,,,4a4f272bc,0.html |title=USCIRF Annual Report 2009 - The Commission's Watch List: Somalia |publisher=Unhcr.org |date=2009-05-01 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} A power sharing deal ensued between an Islamist splinter group led by Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed's Alliance for the Re-liberation of Somalia Djibouti faction (ARS-D) and TFG Prime Minister Nur Hassan in [[Djibouti]]. Al-Shabaab, which had separated from the moderate Islamists of the insurgency, rejected the peace deal and continued to take territories. It was joined by [[Hizbul Islam]], which is an amalgamation of four Islamist group including the Alliance for the Re-liberation of Somalia - [[Asmara]] faction. Another Islamist group, Ahlu Sunnah Waljama'ah, which was allied with the TFG and supported by Ethiopia, continues to attack al-Shabaab and take over towns as well although they have been effective only in the central region of [[Galguduud]], where they ousted al-Shabaab from most of the region.{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/africa/news/article_1456455.php/Moderate_Islamists_seize_town_from_Somali_insurgents_ |title=Moderate Islamists seize town from Somali insurgents |publisher=Monstersandcritics.com |date=2009-01-29 |accessdate=2011-04-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.mareeg.com/fidsan.php?sid=10277&tirsan=3 |title=Moderate Islamic group claims victory over rival hardline group |publisher=Mareeg.com |date=1996-01-01 |accessdate=2011-04-20}}{{cite web|url=http://ethioforum.org/wp/archives/759 |title=Ahlu Suna Wal Jamea supported by Ethiopian government |publisher=Ethioforum.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} After the parliament took in 275 officials from the moderate Islamist opposition, ARS leader Sheikh Ahmed was elected TFG President on January 31, 2009.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/WORLD/africa/01/31/somalia.election.president/ |title=Moderate Islamist picked as Somali president |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=2009-01-31 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} Since then, the al-Shabaab radical Islamists have accused the new TFG President of accepting the secular transitional government and have continued the civil war since he arrived in Mogadishu at the presidential palace in early February 2009.{{cite news|last=Sheikh |first=Abdi |url=http://in.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idINIndia-37897920090207 |title=Rebels target new president |publisher=In.reuters.com |date= 2009-02-07|accessdate=2011-04-20}} ==Timeline== {{main|2009 timeline of the War in Somalia|2010 timeline of the War in Somalia|2011 timeline of the War in Somalia}} ===Islamist-ARS/TFG coalition conflict=== On February 4, 2009, four Islamist groups, including Hassan Dahir Aweys' Eritrean branch of the [[Alliance for the Reliberation of Somalia|ARS]] merged and created the group [[Hisbi Islam]], to fight the new government of Sharif Ahmed. [[al-Shabaab (Somalia)|al-Shabaab]] also vowed to fight the government.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200902050135.html Islamist Groups Merge to Fight Sheikh Sharif] On February 8, 2009, they declared war on the new government of Sharif Ahmed and the AU peace-keepers.[http://allafrica.com/stories/200902080003.html Islamic Party Insurgents Declare War On New Govt] New TFG President Sheik Sharif Sheik Ahmed arrived in Mogadishu as a president for the first time on February 7, 2009. The al-Shabaab and other radical Islamists began firing at the new TFG president hours later. They accused the new President of accepting the secular transitional government.[http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g7OaI4_kjeHA-o4UhlmP7vlWmrrwD966RU880 Radical Islamists attack new president Ahmed's palace]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} On February 8, heavy fighting broke out in southern [[Mogadishu]].{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/Detail.aspx?id=85107§ionid=351020501 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} [[al-Shabaab (Somalia)|al-Shabaab]] leader Sheikh Mukhtar Robow (Abu Mansur). met with Sharif Ahmed for peace talks during his visit to [[Mogadishu]], while Omar Iman rejected the president.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=85097§ionid=351020501 |title=Somali president gears up for peace |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} During these negotiations, Sharif Ahmed said that he would be prepared to enforce [[Sharia Law]] in Somalia, which is currently the radical groups' main demand.http://allafrica.com/stories/200902091418.html However, Sheikh Mukhtar Robow, a former Al-Shabab spokesman,{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200905140395.html |title=Somalia: Al Shabaab Leader Speaks, More Fighting in Mogadishu |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-05-13 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} denied having talked to Sharif Ahmed and vowed to continue fighting until his demands for Sharia Law were met. Sheikh Mukhtar Robow warned [[Nigeria]] against sending peace keepers to Somalia, as al-Shabaab views the AU peace keepers as occupying forces and will continue fighting them until they withdraw from the country.http://allafrica.com/stories/200902120738.html On February 10, al-Shabaab launched an offensive to take the Bakool province. Government officials who had been ousted from Baidoa had been amassing troops in the city of Hudur (Xudur) and planning a major offensive to re-take Baidoa. Islamist forces attacked the province and reached the capital were they started a battle against government forces.http://allafrica.com/stories/200902110007.htmlhttp://allafrica.com/stories/200902100717.html In Galmudug, Clan militia took the town of Masagaway from al-Shabaab. There was also fighting in Warsheekh.http://allafrica.com/stories/200902110654.html On February 12, the spokesman for al-Shabaab, Sheikh Mukhtar Robow (Abu Mansur), rebuffed reports from several media outlets that a mutual agreement between him and newly elected president Sharif Ahmed was made. He also added that he had no intention to contact the president on any matters, and that they would continue fighting against foreign troops and what he described as an âapostate" government.http://www.hiiraan.com/news2/2009/Feb /al_shabaab_reiterates_opposition_to_new_somali_leader.aspx The same day, they vowed war against the new government.http://allafrica.com/stories/200902120954.html {{main|2009 African Union base bombing in Mogadishu|Battle of South Mogadishu}} On February 22, a double suicide bomb attack on an AU base in Mogadishu left 11 Burundian soldiers dead and another 15 wounded. Two days later heavy fighting erupted in the city as TFG and AU forces attempted to retake the city from radical Islamist forces. The fighting lasted for two days and killed 87 people, including: 48 civilians, 15 insurgents and 6 TFG policemen. At the same time as the fighting raged in Mogadishu, al-Shabaab forces took the town of Hudor, to the north-west, in fighting that killed another 20 people: 10 TFG soldiers, 6 insurgents and 4 civilians. On February 28, it appeared that [[Hisbi Islam]] would sign a ceasefire with the [[Transitional Federal Government]].{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2009/02/2009228161951283106.html|title=Somalia in truce with rebel group|date=2009-02-28|accessdate=2009-03-20|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]}} However, by March 1, it was clear that no ceasefire would be given, despite President [[Sharif Ahmed]] having agreed to proposals for a [[truce]] and having offered to accept the implementation of [[Sharia|Sharia Law]] but refused to move troops from civilian areas despite the Islamists doing so.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2009/03/20093117498433881.html|title=Somali rebels reject ceasefire|date=2009-03-01|accessdate=2009-03-20|publisher=[[Al Jazeera]]}}[http://www.somaliweyn.org/pages/news/Mar_09/4Mar23.html ]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} On May 6, al-Shabaab announced that it would continue the war even if AMISOM withdrew.{{cite web|author=|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200905060875.html |title=Somalia: Al Shabaab to 'Continue War' Even If African Union Withdraws |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-05-06 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} May 25, the government announced an immediate blockade on airstrips and seaports under insurgent control to stop the flow of weapons reaching them.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=96013§ionid=351020501 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} {{main|Battle of Mogadishu (2009)}} On May 7, a fierce battle for control of Mogadishu started between al-Shabaab and Hizbul Islam against the TFG. Hundreds were killed and injured and tens of thousands were displaced. By May 11, rebel forces gained the upper hand and made large gains taking over most of the capital. Fighting continued until 14 May and, though they came close, the rebels didn't manage to overthrow the government. There were new rounds of fighting all through August. May 16, al-Shabaab captured the strategic town of [[Jowhar]], which connects Mogadishu with central Somalia.{{cite web|author=Sun May 17 23:30:24 2009 |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200905170014.html |title=Somalia: Al-Shabab Captures Strategic Town |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-05-17 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} {{main|Battle of Wabho}} June 5, Hizbul Islam captured Wabho in one of the largest battles of the war, which left 123 combatants killed. It was also rumoured Sheikh Hassan Dahir Aweys was injured in this battle.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200906070007.html |title=Somalia: 50 Killed in Central Somalia Clashes, Aweys 'Wounded' |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-06-07 |accessdate=2011-04-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=97300§ionid=351020501 |title=No Operation |publisher=Presstv.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On June 19, the transitional parliament speaker Sheikh [[Adan Mohamed Nuur Madobe]] asked the international community to send foreign troops to Somalia within the following 24 hours. He stated that the government's power is on the verge of being defeated by Islamist forces in the Somali capital.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906200013.html Parliament Asks Foreign Troops to Come Within 24 Hours], 19 June 2009 The Cabinet declared a [[state of emergency]]{{cite news|author=The Associated Press|title=Somali Cabinet OKs state of emergency|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5g7OaI4_kjeHA-o4UhlmP7vlWmrrwD98UDFL01|publisher=Google|accessdate=2009-06-21}} and Somalia asked for help from neighbors Kenya, Djibouti, Ethiopia and Yemen. Ethiopia refused saying intervention needs an international mandate.{{cite news|title=Ethiopia rejects Somali request|date=June 21, 2009|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/8111312.stm|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=2009-06-21}} On June 21, a spokesman for the al-Shabaab Islamists said they would fight any foreign troops.{{cite news|author=Mohamed, Ibrahim|date=June 21, 2009|title=Islamists vow to fight any foreign troops in Somalia|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/africaCrisis/idUSLL436226|work=Reuters|publisher=Thompson Reuters|accessdate=2009-06-21}} al-Qaeda also made threats against Kenyan intervention.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200906220999.html |title=East Africa: Al-Qaeda Threat to Peace in East Africa |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-06-21 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} June 22, Somali President Sheikh Sharif Ahmed declared state of emergency in the country as a new round of fighting in Mogadishu left 12 dead and 20 injured. Hundreds were said to be fleeing the city{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200906230001.html |title=Somalia: President Declares State of Emergency, 12 Killed in Mogadishu Clashes |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-06-22 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} July 4, Sheik Abdinasir Jalil, a former commander of the training for ICU administration in Beledweyn town joined Hizbul Islam with is men and vowed to fight TFG forces in the city and attack Ethiopian forces in El-gal village, which lies 18 km from Beledweyn. He said that the government officials want to bring Ethiopian troops inside town and that is the reason they switched sides. Former ICU officials who joined Hizbul Islam, held a press conference and announced that the ICU administration in Hiraan had collapsed as they joined the insurgents.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061032.html Officials Say 'They Will Attack the TFG And Ethiopian Troops in Hiran Region'], July 5, 2009 Sheikh Ibrahim Yusuf, a top security commander in Beledweyn, also defected along with his forces. General Muktar Hussein Afrah was sent to Beledweyn along with TFG troops and put in charge there by the TFG as the ICU administration had collapsed.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061088.html Military Tensions High in Hiran Region Near Ethiopia Border], 5 July 2009 Many ICU officials including MPs resigned that day next to Sheikh Abdinasir Jalil Ahmed (head of training) and Sheikh Ibrahim Yusuf (head of security); Sheik [[Osman Abdulle Barqadle]], the army commander of Ugas Khalif airport, and Sheik Abdullahi Garamgaram, the deputy chief of the emergency forces also resigned.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061406.html Officials Say 'Pro Government Icu Administration in Hiran Region Collapses'], 5 July 2009 In response, TFG forces led by general Muktar Hussein Afrah started military manoeuvers in the East side of the city.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061407.html TFG Soldiers Start Military Movements in Beledweyn Town], 4 July 2009 July 6, Sheikh [[Moktar Ali Zubeyr]], the Amir of al-Shabaab gave government forces an ultimatum of 5 days to hand over their weapons. The ultimatum was rejected by Indho Ade.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061554.html Harakat Al-Shabab Mujahideen Leader Calls for Government Soldiers to Hand Over Their Weapon With in Five Days], 6 July 2009 July 17, two French security advisors to the government were captured by insurgents.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907180010.html Al-Shabaab Snatch Second French Security Adviser Kidnapped in Mogadishu], 17 July 2009 The Somali government gave permission for French commandos to launch operations inside Somalia to free the 2 French nationals that held by al-Shabaab.[[Press TV]] [http://www.presstv.com/detail.aspx?id=101168§ionid=351020501 Somalia okays French military intervention], 20 June 2009 On July 22, [[France|French]] warships and helicopters were seen near the ports of Mogadishu and Marka as France declared they would undertake military operations to free the two French military advisers who had been captured by insurgents.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907220732.html Warships And Helicopters Seen in Mogadishu And Merka], 23 July 2009 One hostage, Marc Aubriere, escaped a month later in August 2009.[http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/africa/news/article_1497535.php/French-hostage-escapes-captors-in-Somalia-Roundup French hostage escapes captors in Somalia][http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8222835.stm Somalia hostage tells of escape] The second, Denis Allex, was seen in a video released in June 2010 asking for assistance to effect his release.[http://www.reuters.com/article/2010/06/09/us-somalia-hostage-france-idUSTRE6584P320100609 Somali group issues video of French hostage] On September 15, a helicopter raid conducted by the US military killed 6, including a key [[Al-Qaida]] member, Saleh Ali Saleh Nabhan.[[Yahoo! News]] [http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090916/ap_on_an/us_us_somalia_analysis], 15 September 2009 ===Al-Shabaab-Hizbul Islam conflict=== The armed conflict between Hizbul Islam and al-Shabaab began due to a dispute between the faction of the Ras Kamboni Brigades led by Sheikh Ahmed "Madoobe" and al-Shabaab,{{cite web|url=http://somalitalkradio.com/2010/mar/un_report_somalia.pdf |pages= 16 & 18|title=Etpu |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} over a power sharing agreement in [[Kisimayo]]. Hizbul Islam and al-Shabaab had made a power sharing agreement for the city, where the power would rotate between the two factions, with each faction controlling the city for periods of six months. However, due to clan politics al-Shabaab refused to let the power rotation take place.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2009/10/200910185652850176.html |title=Somali factions battle in Kismayo |publisher=English.aljazeera.net |date=2009-10-01 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} This led to internal problems within Hizbul Islam as it's ARS-A and [[JABISO]] factions, which were aligned with al-Shabaab in Hiran and Mogadishu, refused to support the Ras Kamboni Brigades, while Anole remained neutral. It also led to a split within the Ras Kamboni Brigades, with a faction led by Hizbul Islam's deputy chairman Sheikh Hassan "Turki" refusing to back Ahmad "Madoobe" and instead siding with al-Shabaab. On October 1, [[Battle of Kisimayo (2009)|heavy fighting]] broke out. By the afternoon, al-Shabaab controlled most of the city with 12 dead and 70 wounded.[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091001/ap_on_re_af/af_somalia ]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} At least 17 people were killed in during a series of battles overnight on October 5.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_17_killed_in_renewed_clashes_near_Kismayo.shtml |title=17 killed in renewed clashes near Kismayo|publisher=Garowe Online |date=2009-10-05 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} A Hizbul Islam spokesman claimed that they had captured foreign fighters in the battle.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Hizbul_Islam_claims_to_capture_foreign_fighters.shtml |title=Garowe Online |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2009-10-06 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} The battle was decisively won by al-Shabaab which expelled Madbobe's Ras Kamboni Brigade forces from the city.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200912090585.html |title=Somalia: Al-Shabaab's Encirclement Strategy |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=8 December 2009 |accessdate=19 August 2010}} Throughout November 2009, fighting between the two factions continued in Southern Somalia and as result insurgent attacks in Mogadishu targeting TFG and AMISOM forces decreased. However [[Ahmed Mohamed Islam|Sheikh Ahmad Madobe]]'s forces were soon overpowered by al-Shabaab and it's local allies and forced to withdraw from the [[Jubbada Hoose|Lower Jubba region]] and most of Southern Somalia. In February 2010, Sheikh Hassan Turki's branch of the Ras Kamboni Brigades declared a merge with al-Shabaab. He encouraged other groups in Hizbul Islam also to join al-Shabaab.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201002020211.html |title=Somalia: Notorious Islamist Guerrilla Leader Joins Al Shabaab |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-02-01 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} In early 2010 the two groups clashed in Hiran region, in central Somalia. This battle was also won by al-Shabaab which took control of the region.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201012130489.html |title=Somalia: Clam Returns to Bur-Hakaba After One Day of Deadly Fighting |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-12-12 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} In late 2010 they also expelled Hizbul Islam from [[Bay, Somalia|Bay region]] after seizing control of Bur Hakab, after a two days battle in which 30 militants were killed.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201012180008.html |title=Somalia: Al Shabaab Leaders Condemn Each Other Publicly |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-12-18 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} In [[Shabeellaha Hoose|Lower Shabelle region]] al-Shabaab seized control of Hizbul Islam strongholds: Furuqley, Farsooley and Dugulle villages and then started preparing an offensive in [[Afgooye]], the last town Hizbul Islam controlled in the region.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201012140856.html |title=Somalia: Al Shabaab Takes Over Region From Hizbul Islam |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-12-14 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} Soon after Hizbul Islam was forced to surrender the [[Luuq District]] in [[Gedo|Gedo region]] to al-Shabaab, after which it was announced that Hizbul Islam would merge with al-Shabaab. From mid-December al-Shabaab fighters started taking over Hizbul Islam positions.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201012201376.html |title=Somalia: Rival Militant Groups Set to Join Forces |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-12-20 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} Hizbul Islam fighters also started entering al-Shabaab controlled areas of Mogadishu. The merge was confirmed on December 20, when Hizbul Islam Chairman Sheikh Hassan Dahir Aweys and Sheikh Mohammad Osman Arus, the organisation's official spokesman, surrendered to al-Shabaab and disbanded the organisation. ===Galmudug and Islamists=== Government officials from the [[Galmudug]] administration in the north-central [[Hobyo]] district also reportedly attempted to use pirate gangs as a bulwark against Islamist insurgents from southern Somalia's conflict zones.{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/02/world/africa/02pirates.html?pagewanted=1&_r=1&th&emc=th |title=In Somali Civil War, Both Sides Embrace Pirates |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= 2010-09-01|accessdate=2011-03-27 |first=Jeffrey |last=Gettleman}} Other pirates are alleged to have reached agreements of their own with the Islamist groups, although a senior commander from the [[Hizbul Islam]] militia vowed to eradicate piracy by imposing [[sharia law]] when his group briefly took control of Harardhere in May 2010 and drove out the local pirates.{{cite web|last=Haji |first=Mustafa |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j0OwOfeiTIzFFb3Vb2e8dxaI5qHA |title=Somali Islamists vow to end piracy, pirates flee with ships |publisher=Google.com |date=2010-05-02 |accessdate=2011-03-27}} ===Battle of Gashandiga=== An early 2011 offensive was dubbed by AU Representative Wafula Wamunyinyi as the "Battle of Gashandiga." In February 20, 2011, it was reported that AMISOM troops destroyed a large complex of al-Shabaab trenches, and killed six al-Shabaab commanders in Mogadishu. Two AMISOM troops died in those battles.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Press_Releases_32/AMISOM_Smashes_Extremist_s_Urban_Trench_System.shtml |title=Garowe Online |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2011-02-20 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On February 21, at least 20 people, including TFG policemen were killed in a suicide car bomb attack in Mogadishu.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Suicide_car_bomb_killed_20_people_in_Mogadishu.shtml |title=Suicide car bomb killed 20 people in Mogadishu|publisher=Garowe Online |date=2011-02-21 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} Between February 21 and 22, twelve people were killed in heavy shelling in Mogadishu.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_12_killed_in_continue_clashes_in_Mogadishu.shtml |title=12 killed in continued clashes in Mogadishu |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2011-02-22 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On February 25, 15 people were killed as al-Shabaab fighters attempted to re-take lost territory in Mogadishu. Additionally, rebels displayed one wounded and five dead Burundian AMISOM soldiers.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_15_civilians_killed_in_Mogadishu_clashes.shtml |title=15 civilians killed in Mogadishu_clashes |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2011-02-25 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On February 26, an offensive by TFG troops with support of Ethiopian soldiers was opened in the southern Somali town of [[Bula Hawo]]. Until February 28, 33 people were killed in TFG and Ethiopian shelling. By March 5, AMISOM and TFG forces claimed to control seven of the city's districts, while six were contested and three were controlled by anti-government forces. Al-Shabaab responded to the government offensive by putting up roadblocks to prevent the movement of goods from the seaport. This adversely affected both sides of the conflict, as the TFG controlled the port and its profits, while the Bakaara Market, where many of the goods were bound to be sold, was controlled by the insurgents.[http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/174/Ahlu_Sunna_Gedo_Leader_Dies_After_Ambush AMISOM Vows to Keep Fighting for Mogadishu] It was reported that by March 5, up to 53 AMISOM may have died in the clashes. Of those, 43 Burundian and 10 Ugandan.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12650263 | work=BBC News | title=Somalia's al-Shabab 'holds 18 Burundian bodies' | date=March 4, 2011}} By March 16, AMISOM was bolstered by an additional 1,000 peacekeepers to assist in the TFG's renewed offensive against al-Shabaab, bringing the total manpower of AMISOM to nearly 9,000.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12764412 | work=BBC News | title=Ugandan Amisom peacekeepers jailed for shooting Somalis | date=March 16, 2011}} ===Defeat of Al-Shabaab in Mogadishu=== On August 6, 2011, the Transitional Federal Government's troops and their AMISOM allies reportedly managed to capture all of Mogadishu from the Al-Shabaab militants. Witnesses reported Al-Shabaab vehicles abandoning their bases in the capital for the south-central city of [[Baidoa]]. The group's spokesman Sheikh Ali Mohamud Rage described the exodus as a tactical retreat, and vowed to continue the insurgency against the national government. Observers have suggested that the pullout may at least in part have been caused by internal ideological rifts in the rebel organization. After their withdrawal, al-Shabaab has however continued hit and run tactics in the North of the city as they vowed to continue guerilla attacks in Mogadishu.[http://allafrica.com/stories/201108181054.html Govt Forces, Al Shabaab Fight in Mogadishu] On October 4, 2011, a suicide bomb on a lorry detonated and killed more than 70 people near a compound housing several government ministries. Two weeks later a car bomb killed at least two people.{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/2011101813351279957.html |title=Deadly blast hits Somali capital |publisher=AlJazeera |date=2011-10-18 |accessdate=2011-10-18}} On October 11, 2011 AU troops claimed to have driven the remnants of al-Shabaab out of the city.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15263705 |publisher=BCC |date=2011-10-11 |accessdate=2011-10-18 |title=Somalia clashes force Mogadishu hospital to close}} ===Fighting in Puntland=== On 2 September to 3 September, fighting was reported in [[Puntland]] that resulted in the deaths of up to 60 people, including 8 Puntland soldiers and 40 Al-Shabaab militants, with Insurgents being repelled.{{cite news | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/somaliaNews/idAFL5E7K30RD20110903?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 | title=Fighting in Somalia's Puntland kills at least 27 | publisher=Reuters Africa | date=3 September 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/09/heavy-fighting-in-central-somalia-claims-30-lives-2/ | title=Heavy fighting in Central Somalia Claims 30 Lives | publisher=Channel 6 News |date=3 September 2011}} Al-Shabaab claimed on 7 September that they have captured 2 Kenyan troops who were on a surveillance mission near the Kenyan-Somalian Border.{{cite news | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/somali-militants-say-they-have-captured-2-kenyan-soldiers-near-countrys-shared-border/2011/09/07/gIQACHon9J_story.html | title=Somali Militants Say they have Captured 2 Kenyan Soldiers Near the Countries' Shared Border | publisher=Washington Post | date=7 September 2011 | deadurl=yes}} {{Dead link|date=December 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} Puntland forces captured 18 members of Al-Shabaab in counter-terrorism operations on 8 September. ===Battle of Elwaq=== Al-Shabaab attacked the southern town of Elwaq on 10 September, resulting in the deaths of 12 insurgents and soldiers.{{cite news | url=http://af.reuters.com/article/somaliaNews/idAFL5E7KC18Q20110912?pageNumber=2&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true | title=Somali Troops Retake Town After Rebel Raid | publisher=Reuters Africa | date=12 September 2011}} The next day, Somali troops fought back, retaking the town after militants fled on captured [[technical (vehicle)|technicals]]. The bodies of 30 militants were later found, some of them children. Conversely, Al-Shabaab claimed they killed around 70 government aligned troops and captured 10 technicals. The Burundian military lost 51 soldiers in October, causing anger among Burundians, who believe that their country is sacrificing too much. Many Burundians have urged other AU members to contribute troops to the Somalia mission. [[Nigeria]], [[Djibouti]], and [[Guinea]] have indicated sending troops, but all have yet to contributehttp://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iDMfHWg3CtRLmqAzXlV7_HxRVhfw?docId=dac727053c55487784f0d0754adfd82f ==Foreign involvement== ===United States and Other International Involvement=== As of October 2010, the U.S. State Department noted the United States directly obligated over $229 million to support AMISOM, and paid for other UN assistance for the mission indirectly through its obligations to the international body.{{cite web|url=http://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2863.htm|title=Background Note: Somalia |publisher=US State Department|date=2011-01-03|accessdate=2011-05-10}} The [[United National Development Program]] for Somalia spends about $50 million each year,[http://www.so.undp.org/index.php/Donors-and-partners.html UNDP in Somalia: Donors and Expenditures] though these funds are not related to military aid. Instead these programs, such as Employment Generation for Early Recovery (EGER)[http://www.so.undp.org/index.php/Somalia-Stories/Employment-Generation-for-Early-Recovery.html Employment Generation for Early Recovery] are targeted to foster civil government institutions for the Transitional Federal Government, such as law enforcement, local governance, youth employment, watershed management, as well as AIDS/HIV programs. ===Ethiopia=== ====2009==== [[File:Ethiopian Operations.png|thumb|right|Area of Ethiopian operations in Somalia since their official withdrawal in January 2009.]] On February 16, Somali MP [[Mohamud Sayid Adan]], former Mogadishu mayor [[Mohamed Omar Habeeb]] and local police officer Hassan Dhicisow, were arrested by Ethiopian forces in the town of Dolow in Gedo region.{{cite web|url=http://soomaalidamaanta.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=12641:somali-mp-arrested-by-ethiopian-troops&catid=34:english-news&Itemid=51 |title=Somali MP arrested by Ethiopian troops |publisher=Soomaalidamaanta.net |date=2009-02-16 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On May 28, 2 Ethiopian soldiers, 1 Ethiopian civilian, 2 Somali soldiers killed, 4 Somali civilians (working for the government) and 4 Somali insurgents, were killed when insurgents attacked a convoy in carrying [[Omar Hashi Aden]] who was returning from his visit to Ethiopia.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_Security_Minister_attacked_in_Ethiopia.shtml |title=Somalia Security Minister attacked in Ethiopia |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2009-05-28 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On May 31, Ethiopian forces launched search and seizure operations in Hiraan, in Kalaberyr village, near Beledweyn.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906010315.html Ethiopian Troops Make Search Operations in Hiraan Region], 31 May 2009 On June 12, Ethiopian forces with several battle wagons entered in Balanbal town in Galgudud and set up military bases.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906130004.html Ethiopian Troops Reach in Balanbal Town in Central Somalia], 13 June 2009 On June 14, the Ethiopian military said it had come to fight foreign mujahedin which the military described as "foreign enemies of Ethiopia and Somalia" and launched operations to search for them in Balanbal town which they control.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906140007.html Ethiopian Troops Say They Arrived in Balanbal Town to Fight Against Foreign Enemies in Somalia.], 14 June 2009 Sheik Hassan Ya'qub Ali, head of the information affairs for Islamic administration in [[Kisimayo]] warned the Ethiopians that "there is no candy and dates to eat from here in Somalia. But the men who chased you forcibly from the country are here in Somalia."[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906150178.html Islamists Warn the Ethiopian Troops Who Poured in Parts of Central Somalia], 14 June 2009 The suicide bombing on June 18 targeted a meeting between TFG and Ethiopian commanders.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906180880.html http://allafrica.com/stories/200906180880.html], 18 June 2009 On June 19, Ethiopian forces entered Bakool and reached Elberde town. They withdrew after holding talks with local clan elders.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906190134.html Ethiopian Troops Return Back in Bakol Region], 19 June 2009 June 22, Ethiopian forces started launching search and seizure operations in Kala-beyrka intersection in Hiran region.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200906220549.html Ethiopian Troops Start Searching Activities in Central Region], 22 June 2009 The Ethiopian government then announced it would not intervene without an international mandate. June 30, Ethiopian forces entered El-gal and Ilka'adde villages which are less than 20 km north of regional capital Beledweyn. Reports from Kala-beyrka intersection say that more extra troops from Ethiopia crossed from the border.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907020870.html Ethiopian Troops Reach Near Beledweyn Town], 2 July 2009 July 4, Ethiopians withdrew from their bases in Banabal town in Galgudug.[[allafrica]] [http://allafrica.com/stories/200907061405.html Ethiopian Troops Vacate From Balanbal Town], 5 July 2009 July 18, Ethiopian forces vacated their bases in Yed Village in insurgent-controlled Bakool region.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200907200193.html |title=Somalia: Ethiopian Troops Vacate in Yed Village in Southern Somalia |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2009-07-18 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} During the weekend of 29â30 August, Ethiopian forces advanced to Beledweyne, supporting a government offensive on the insurgent part of, Beledweyne. They withdrew on August 31. The assault on Beledweyne by government forces came as the TFG governor of Hiraan (belonging to Sharif Ahmed's ARS-Djibouti faction), [[Sheikh Abdirahman Ibrahim Ma'ow]], which controls the other part of Beledweyne, withdrew his administration's support for the TFG.{{cite web|url=http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/As_Ethiopia_withdraws_Hiran_governor_quits_Somalia_government.shtml |title=As Ethiopia withdraws Hiran governor quits Somalia_government |publisher=Garowe Online |date=2009-08-31 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} ====2010==== March 19, [[Mohammed wali Odowa]], spokesman of Hizbul Islam's Hiraan administration in Beledweyne, threatened that Hizbul Islam forces would attack any Ethiopian forces which entered Hizbul Islam controlled territories in Hiraan.{{cite web|url=http://www.somaliweyn.org/pages/news/Mar_10/19Mar15.html |title=Somalia: Hizbul-Islam in Hiran region vows to attack Ethiopian troops |publisher=Somaliweyn.org |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} May 20, Ethiopian forces seized control of the previously al-Shabaab held towns of Yeed and [[Ceelbare District|Elbarde]], in Bakool region.[http://iftiimiye.net/?p=4060 BAIDOA (Sunatimes)âEthiopian troops have re-entered Somalia and seize two Somali towns from the extremist rebel group of Alshabaab in two days, according to witnesses on Wedne...]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} Al-Shabaab had captured Elbarde from the TFG on April 20.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201004230586.html |title=Somalia: Ethiopia Troops Expel Al Shabaab From Border Town |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-04-22 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On July 18, Ethiopian forces withdrew from all their bases in Hiraan and Bakool regions. Ethiopian forces had held these territories for two months, during which they clashed several times with al-Shabaab forces which control most of Hiraan. Before they withdrew they released over 20 lorries which used to travel between the South and Central regions of Somalia.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201007210230.html |title=Somalia: Ethiopian Troops Leave From a Village in Hiran Region |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-07-18 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} August 27, 1,000 Ethiopian troops entered Somalia through the border town of Dolo, were 6,000 Ethiopian forces are based. They advanced deep into Gedo region in the direction of the towns of Beledehawa and Elwak, accompanied by militia of pro-Ethiopian, Somali warlords.http://www.golisnews.com/other-links/the-scramble-for-somalia/ In Hiraan, Ethiopian forces which entered along with TFG-forces exchanged fire with al-Shabaab militants and advanced until the Kalaber junction, near Beledweyne. The Ethiopian troops then withdrew to Ferfer.{{cite news| url=http://articles.cnn.com/2010-08-27/world/somalia.militants.offensive_1_ethiopian-troops-abdirahman-omar-osman-ethiopian-forces?_s=PM:WORLD | work=CNN | title=Islamist fighters seize Somali government seat | date=26 January 2009}} August 29, there was a second Ethiopian incursion. A large number of Ethiopian forces in military vehicles, accompanied by highly trained TFG forces, entered several villages in al-Shabaab controlled Hiraan region. This came at a time when al-Shabaab militants regularly ventured near the border. Hussein Abdallah, an ASWJ loyalist claimed that the movements were a preliminary action to signal that Ethiopian authorities are able of weakening the Islamist insurgents, to al-Shabaab's leadership.{{cite web|url=http://www.hiiraan.com/news2/2010/aug/ethiopia_troops_in_somalia_to_battle_radicals.aspx |title=Ethiopia troops in Somalia to battle radicals |publisher=Hiiraan.com |date= |accessdate=2011-04-20}} September 1, Ethiopian forces moved deeper into Gedo region, via Dolow, entering the TFG-held village of Yeed. TFG officials in the region reported they were planning to capture the entire Bay and Bakool regions from al-Shabaab. December 30, TFG forces clashed with Ethiopian troops in the Jawil district, near Beledweyne, after Ethiopian forces took a TFG soldier into custody. One TFG soldier and one civilian were injured in the clashes.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201012300419.html |title=Somalia: Govt Forces, Ethiopian Military Clash in Central Region |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2010-12-30 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} ====2011==== January 3, Ahlu Sunna Waljamaa official [[Sheikh Abdi Badel Sheikh Abdullahi]], complained about Ethiopian forces in the town of Dolo, in Gedo region. The town is controlled by 300 ASWJ and TFG forces, but it is also home to several Ethiopian military bases. Ethiopian forces had called on ASWJ fighters in the district to lay down their arms. According to a TFG official, three Ethiopian commanders had then come to the town of Dolo and ordered TFG forces to disarm. Ethiopian troops then disarmed a number of TFG and ASWJ forces. Sheikh Abdullahi alleged that Ethiopian forces were doing this because they were outraged by ASWJ's military capability.{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201101030695.html |title=Somalia: Moderate Ahlu Sunna Complain of Ethiopian Forces |publisher=allAfrica.com |date=2011-01-03 |accessdate=2011-04-20}}{{cite web|url=http://www.shabelle.net/article.php?id=1613 |title=Somalia: Moderate Ahlu Sunna complain of Ethiopian forces |publisher=Shabelle |date=2010-11-03 |accessdate=2011-04-20}} On November 19, eyewitness reported large number of Ethiopian troops crossing into Somalia. Ethiopian authorities denied this.{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-15807215 |publisher=BBC |title=Ethiopian troops 'cross border into Somalia' |author=Will Ross |date=19 November 2011 |accessdate=20 November 2011}} ===Kenya=== ====Recruitment from Kenya==== According to press reports, Somali and Kenyan government officials have recruited and trained Somali refugees in Kenya and Kenyan nationals who are ethnic Somalis to fight insurgents in Somalia. However, the Somali chief of military staff and spokesmen from the Kenyan government have denied this.[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20091116/ap_on_re_af/af_kenya_secret_militia ]{{dead link|date=April 2011}} ====2010 Kenya-Somalia border clash==== {{Main|2010 KenyaâSomalia border clash}} On July 20, 2010 border clashes between Kenya and Somalia occurred, when gunmen from the [[al-Shabaab]] militia attacked a Kenyan border patrol along the border area in [[Liboi]], [[Lagdera Constituency|Lagdera]]. There was a subsequent fierce exchange of fire between the two sides leading to the deaths of 2 militia and the wounding of one Kenyan officer.Ali, Noor.[http://af.reuters.com/article/kenyaNews/idAFLDE66J1TM20100720?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true 2 Kenyan forces, al-Shabaab rebels clash on border], Reuters, July 20, 2010. Hundreds of security personnel were later deployed to the border following the clash and because of continued fighting between two militia groups in the neighbouring town of Dobley, Somalia.[http://www.standardmedia.co.ke/InsidePage.php?id=2000014901&cid=4&ttl=Border%20security%20intensified%20as%20rival%20militias%20clash Border security intensified as rival militias clash], The Standard, July 29, 2010. The Somali rebel group had previously claimed responsibility for a deadly suicide bombing in [[July 2010 Kampala attacks|Uganda in July]]. ====Operation Linda Nchi==== {{main|Operation Linda Nchi}} In October 2011, in a coordinated military operation with the [[Military of Somalia|Somalian military]], [[Kenya Defence Forces|Kenyan troops]] crossed the border into southern Somalia in pursuit of [[Al-Shabaab]] militants that are alleged to have kidnapped several foreign tourists and workers inside Kenya.[http://www.defenceweb.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=20085:kenyan-ramps-up-security-at-somali-border-eyes-al-shabaab&catid=49:National Security&Itemid=115 Kenyan ramps up security at Somali border, eyes al Shabaab]{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2011/10/20111016115410991692.html|agency=Al Jazeera English|date=16 October 2011|accessdate=16 October 2011|title=Kenyan troops pursue al-Shabab into Somalia in Operation Linda Nchi}} The incursion was reportedly spearheaded by Kenya's Minister of Defence, [[Mohamed Yusuf Haji]], an ethnic Somali. Although the Kenyan Army's role in the operation is active, a spokesman for the [[Transitional Federal Government]] of Somalia (TFG) indicated that Kenyan troops were only supplying "logistical and moral support" and that Somalian military officers were actually combating the Islamist militants. On 17 October, media reported that TFG forces had taken control of the town of Qoqani.{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201110180138.html|agency=allAfrica.com|title=Kenya: Army Hit Somali Terror Base|date=17 October 2011|accessdate=18 October 2011}} ==See also== *[[List of wars 2003âcurrent]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{War on Terrorism|state=collapsed}} {{IslamismNorthAfrica}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Somalia War (2009â)}} [[Category:War in Somalia (2009â)| ]] [[Category:2009 in Somalia|War in Somalia (2009â)]] [[Category:2010 in Somalia|War in Somalia (2009â)]] [[Category:2011 in Somalia|War in Somalia (2009â)]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2009]] [[Category:Civil wars post-1945]] [[Category:Somali Civil War]] [[ar:Ø­Ø±Ø¨ Ø§ÙØµÙÙØ§Ù (2009â)]] [[ko:2009ë ìë§ë¦¬ì ì ì]] [[pl:Wojna w Somalii (2009-)]]
